scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The components of the collection are the personal and business papers of John Jaquelin Ambler (1801-1854) of Glenambler, Amherst County, Virginia, a landowner and farmer, of his father in law Philip Pendleton Barbour (1783-1841) of Orange County, Virginia, a lawyer, politician, and jurist: approximately half of the collection derives from each man.

Ambler's papers include containing a brief autobiography to 1823, the journal of his travels in Europe during 1823-1826, an autobiography for the years 1826-1836; estate accounts for Glenambler and a second property called St. Moor; and business or personal correspondence of Ambler, his wife Elizabeth Barbour Ambler, parents John Ambler (1762-1836) and Catherine Bush Abler (1773-1846), half brother Daniel Norborn Norton (1794-1842), brothers Philip St. George (1806-1877) and Richard Cary Ambler (1810-1877), sister-in-law and mother-in-law Philippa and Mrs. Philip Pendleton Barbour, and various other members of the Ambler and Barbout families. The estate and business papers, related to Lynchburg, Campbell and Amhurst counties, Virginia, concern sales of crops, charges for labor and supplies, and Ambler's keen interest in fine horses and acquisition of lands. The personal correspondence originates in Amherst County, Richmond, and Orange County in Virginia, and in Washington, D.C.

Barbour's papers include four accounts books recording charges and payments for legal services ca. 1806-1828 rendered during his practice in Charlottesville, and in Albemarle, Louisa, Madison, Orange, and King and Queen counties, in Virginia, as well as legal correspondence and receipts and other papers arising from the law practice and the business of Barbour's plantation, 1801-1829. The collection offers very little material on Barbour's political and judicial career.

did.unittitle:
Journal of John Jaquelin Ambler of "Glen Ambler,"
1801-1854.
did.physdesc: 4 vols., each with his armorial bookplate.

did.unittitle: Volume 1.

scopecontent.p: The first volume opens with "Memoranda of the life of John Jaqueline Ambler of Glen Ambler" (pp.1-19), a brief autobiography of the writer up to August 1823 when he embarked on the East Indiaman Palambam, Capt. George Simpson, for London. Ambler's journal follows (pp. 1-329), with an account of his travels August 1823- September 1824 in England, France, Belgium, Holland, Germany, Switzerland and Italy.

did.unittitle: Volume 2.

scopecontent.p: Covers Ambler's travels September 1824- August 1825 in Italy, France, and England.

did.unittitle: Volume 3.

scopecontent.p: Records his residence in England August- December 1825.

did.unittitle: Volume 4.

Letters of Philip Pendleton Barbour to John Jaquelin Ambler, his wife Elizabeth Barbour Ambler, and his mother-in-law, Mrs. Frances T. Barbour,
1832-1847.

bioghist.p: Philip Pendleton Barbour (1783-1841), a lawyer of Orange County, was member of the General Assembly 1812-1814; House Representative from Va., 1814-1821; speaker, 1821-1823; judge of Virginia judiciary 1825; Congress 1827-1830; president VA Court Convention, 1829-1830; chairman of judiciary committee; president Philadelphia free trade convention, 1831. Was appointed associate justice of U.S. Supreme Court in 1836. Judge US District Court 1830.

scopecontent.p: Most of the letters are from Ambler brothers and Mrs. Barbour's children.
